620832d09e1a18cad9e0f3a1cdf98002 (01:47): With two hard disks,
620832d09e1a18cad9e0f3a1cdf98002 (01:48): is it better to mirror them using solaris volume manager, or to install on one and assign raw access to the other to Oracle?
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (01:48): thats two completly different scenarios... do you need the redundancy or not?
620832d09e1a18cad9e0f3a1cdf98002 (01:49): we have a failover machine
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (01:49): either the disks are not a single point of failure, or they are two single points of failure
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (01:49): i would never go without redundant disks
620832d09e1a18cad9e0f3a1cdf98002 (01:49): aha. i kind of agree
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (01:49): and i would never got for less than six disks for a production system
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (01:50): or i would prefer not to :)
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (01:50): i'm often forced to go with four drives... like on a sun v440 or t2000
620832d09e1a18cad9e0f3a1cdf98002 (01:50): hmm. I have to make do with two
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (01:50): Squeeeez: system, data, logs
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (01:51): or perhaps system, data, log+index... or other config as well... depending on the workload
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (01:52): it's almost suprising how fast a dirt cheap dell 2850 with six drives can be
620832d09e1a18cad9e0f3a1cdf98002 (01:52): how best to slice the disk for performance, assuming mirroring?
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (01:53): Zauephuaes: i would go for zfs ... rock solid and fast mirroring
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (01:53): Zauephuaes: and it supports compression at the fs level... which gives damn fast data access

443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (01:54): yes, zfs is faster with compression turned on .. since the cpu often idles while waiting for blocks from disk.. fewer blocks from disk means more cpu time consumed but less ideling... cool cool
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (01:54): i should say, zfs is _often_ faster ...
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (01:54): on my crappy 4200rpm laptop drive it is 2.5x faster sometimes...
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (01:54): since any block saved is a huge improvement
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (01:55): so, one / slice, one /var and then a massive zfs disk of the rest
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (01:55): ah, and one metadb slice... and possibly two more slices for LU
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (01:56): thats 7 i think.. yes
